prompt:
A chat between a curious user and an artificial intelligence assistant. The assistant gives helpful, detailed, and polite answers to the user's questions. USER: Please answer my code questions using the given API following this format: <<<api>>>: $API
<<<code>>>: $CODE
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION.
Question: Reading A File and Storing It In An Object: :I am trying to read from a file and store the contents into an object called ToDoList(from what I assume is under the GetItem method). Then I am supposed to allow the user to add on to the list. But I am lost on how to create the object and print it.public class ToDoList {private ToDoItem[] items;ToDoItem td = new ToDoItem();String inputline;Scanner keyboard = new Scanner(System.in);int i = 0;String[] stringArray = new String[100];private void setItems(ToDoItem[] items) throws FileNotFoundException {    File file = new File("ToDoItems.txt");    Scanner ReadFile = new Scanner(file);    while (ReadFile.hasNext()) {        String ListString = ReadFile.nextLine();        stringArray[100] = (ListString);    }}private ToDoItem[] getItems() {    return items;}public void addItem(int id, String description) {    stringArray[100] = (td.getId() + td.getDescription());}public String[] getAddItem() throws FileNotFoundException {    try (PrintWriter fout = new PrintWriter(new File("ToDoItems.txt"))) {        do {            System.out.println("add to the list? [y/n]");            inputline = keyboard.nextLine();            if ("y".equals(inputline)) {                i++;                stringArray[i] = (td.getId() + ". " + td.getDescription() + "\n");                fout.print(stringArray[i]);            } else {                System.out.println("Here is the list so far:");            }        } while ("y".equals(inputline));        return stringArray;    }}@Overridepublic String toString() {    return "ToDoList{" + "items=" + getItems()            + '}';}I am supposed to use the "getAddItem" method to allow the user to add to the list. But I can't figure out how to add an array to an object. let alone make the object.  
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.
Answer: ASSISTANT:
response:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer("ToDoList");
String className = st.nextToken();
String objectName = st.nextToken();
```java
    ToDoList object = null;
    try {
        object = (ToDoList) Class.forName(className).getDeclaredConstructor().newInstance();
    } catch (Exception e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    }

    Object[] items = object.getItems();
    for (int i = 0; i < items.length; i++) {
        System.out.println(items[i]);
    }
```
<<<explanation>>>: This code uses the StringTokenizer class to parse the input string "ToDoList" into its component parts: the class name and the object name. It then creates an instance of the ToDoList class using the "getDeclaredConstructor" method and the "newInstance" method. The "Class.forName" method is used to get the class object for the specified class name. The "items" field of the ToDoList object is then accessed to print its contents.
